nodes.text: Should the UK implement internet censorship?
Violates freedom of speech, thus violates basic human rights.
Internet censorship is vital to national security.
Security of the person is also a basic human right which is violated without internet censorship.
Freedom of speech may be a basic human right but exceptions must be made when hate speech or threats for example are made.
Attempting to implement censorship of the whole internet is not economically viable.
Censorship does not tackle the source of the problem, it merely removes it from the public eye.
By removing vulgar content from the internet, the idea is likely to spread if it is not easily accessible, thus eventually reducing the number of producers of such content.
The rapid growth of the internet means it would require a substantial amount of resources to censor such a vast network.
Tv, radio, billboards etc are all subject to a degree of censorship, why should the internet be any different?
Censorship of the internet could help deter the piracy of media which could protect the rights of those who own the material.
ISP have already attempted to censor certain torrent sites and have failed to have an impact on access to these sites.
Internet censorship could see the demise of the criminal underworld of the internet which may have an effect on overall crime rates.
The number of instances where the internet has caused a breach of national security are few in number, whereas internet censorship would remove a human right which affected the entire population.
